author: @bckahraman
text: For those who are running into the Apache issue related with the virtual environments:  There is a solution in the Flask website actually explaining what to do in the case of working with virtual environments, Here at the bottom : http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/0.12/deploying/mod_wsgi/#working-with-virtual-environments  Add the following lines to the top of your .wsgi file:  activate_this = '/path/to/env/bin/activate_this.py' execfile(activate_this, dict(__file__=activate_this))  This is the official solution for this problem. Installing flask outside of your virtual environment is a workaround in this case.

author: @Wacuzn
text: Hey guys. If you are trying run python3 same as me, it is important for you to install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 not libapache2-mod-wsgi. If not, Apache will use python2 instead and you will get 500 internal error. If you have different struggle then us, try follow errors in /var/log/apache2/error.log file. Wish you luck.

author: @jcf3300
text: Okay, so many have brought up the "digital ocean DEFAULT PAGE response" question. I too had that problem; I was directed to the default page NOT my app's page. For me, the issue revolved around working in python3 instead of python2. While I thought I had made sure to use python3 throughout the setup process (i.e. pip3 installs, shebang path, etc.), I hadn't actually installed mod_wsgi for apache for python3. The following command resolved the issue:  ''' apt-get install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 ''' Now reload & restart apache and try the server name again in the browser.   Hope that helps.

author: @Vl4diii
text: !!!! Apache default page soulution For those who are struggling and asking why everytime the apache default page appears. Here is the solution:  cd /etc/apache2/sites-available  (optional: Saving the files in home directory cp 000-default.conf /home cp default-ssl.conf /home) rm 000-default.conf rm default-ssl.conf  /etc/apache2/sites-enabled rm 000-default.conf  service apache2 reload service apache2 restart  Now it should work. Have fun

author: @nathanielvala9929
text: Hey @sentdex! Thank so much for these videos, they are super helpful! I have been able to follow along with other tutorials locally however when I tried to move it online the .wsgi file keeps failing on the "ImportError: No module named FlaskApp" throwing a 500 error presumably because it isnt in the virtual environment. I solved this by using "sudo apt-get install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3" and instead of using "#! /usr/bin/python" using: "#! /var/www/SSP/SSP/VE/bin/python  activate_this = '/var/www/SSP/SSP/VE/bin/activate_this.py' with open(activate_this) as file_:     exec(file_.read(), dict(__file__=activate_this))"  Hope this helps some people!

author: @deadalusdx5637
text: If you did everything from the tutorial and still getting a 500 Internal Server Error, make the following changes:   $->>>  nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/FlaskApp.conf  <VirtualHost *:80>                 ServerName 81.4.110.198                 ServerAdmin youemail@email.com                 WSGIDaemonProcess FlaskApp python-path=/var/www/FlaskApp:/var/w$                 WSGIProcessGroup FlaskApp                 WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/FlaskApp/flaskapp.wsgi                 <Directory /var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/>                         Order allow,deny                         Allow from all                 </Directory>                 Alias /static /var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/static                 <Directory /var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/static/>                         Order allow,deny                         Allow from all                 </Directory>                 ErrorLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/error.log                 LogLevel warn                 CustomLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/access.log combined </VirtualHost>    If you want a domain to point to your Flask Application, do the following:  $->>>  nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/FlaskApp.conf   <VirtualHost *:80>                 ServerName http://www.mywebsite.com                 ServerAdmin youemail@email.com                 WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/FlaskApp/flaskapp.wsgi                 <Directory /var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/>                         Order allow,deny                         Allow from all                 </Directory>                 Alias /static /var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/static                 <Directory /var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/static/>                         Order allow,deny                         Allow from all                 </Directory>                 ErrorLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/error.log                 LogLevel warn                 CustomLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/access.log combined </VirtualHost>

author: @bradyanderson2250
text: If you're having errors (internal server error - 500), it could be that when you install Flask in your virtualenv, you installed in python2. To ensure that you're installing python3 on your server, type apt-get install python3-pip, rather than apt-get install python-pip. Then as lllForneronlll pointed out, make sure Flask is installed outside of your virtualenv (pip install flask).

author: @carlosfranciscomontenegro620
text: Hello, I was having an issue with the wsgi code... and found that it was due to the virtual env. So if you are using virtualenv and having an "Import error: No module named flask" like error then try de code below. Cheers  import os, sys  PROJECT_DIR = '/var/www/FlaskApp'  activate_this = os.path.join(PROJECT_DIR, 'FlaskApp', 'venv', 'bin', 'activate_this.py') execfile(activate_this, dict(__file__=activate_this)) sys.path.append(PROJECT_DIR)   from FlaskApp import app as application application.secret_key = 'testtestkeykey'

author: @nate237gmail
text: Like others I ran into the situation where Apache wouldn't work with the virtual environment.  From /var/log/apache2/error_log you'll see something along the lines of "ImportError: No module named flask"  I followed some instructions for Django at  https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-run-django-with-mod_wsgi-and-apache-with-a-virtualenv-python-environment-on-a-debian-vps  In short, to fix:  1.  Edit /etc/apache2/sites-available/FlaskApp.conf 2.  Add the following two lines before the "WSGIScriptAlias" line:        WSGIDaemonProcess FlaskApp python-path=/var/www/FlaskApp:/var/www/FlaskApp/FlaskApp/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages        WSGIProcessGroup FlaskApp 3.  Restart Apache with "service apache2 restart"  It should work now.

author: @paulransfield
text: hi harrison ... i crashed my initial flask app ... to restore, i had to:  1 ¬† Add these two lines of code into the FlaskApp.wsgi file ...¬†  activate_this = '/{{ add your path to your virtual environment here }} /bin/activate_this.py' execfile(activate_this, dict(__file__=activate_this))  2 ¬† Change my app.py to __init__.py  I accept that if I had followed your advice and not develop on a production server, I may not have had this issue ... however, if you want multiple tools on your production server, I think at some stage these two lines need to be added into the FlaskApp.wsgi file  Thanks very much - love your tutorials
